articles.headline: For Student Borrowers, Relief Now May Mean a Big Tax Bill Later
articles.snippet: Two federal loan programs that include loan forgiveness can result in a huge tax bill years later when the remaining balance is forgiven.
articles.abstract: Two federal loan programs that include loan forgiveness can result in a huge tax bill years later when the remaining balance is forgiven.
articles.lead_paragraph: Those breathing a sigh of relief that their student loan payments are now in line with their income may want to re-examine the rules that set the payment in the first place. There could be a tax time bomb looming, slowly ticking away. And defusing it is not a big part of the policy discussion in Washington at the moment.

articles.headline: Message, if Murky, From U.S. to the World
articles.snippet: The United States’ refusal to sign a global treaty on telecommunications — even though it got most of what it wanted — is seen as taking a stand for Internet freedom.
articles.abstract: The United States’ refusal to sign a global treaty on telecommunications — even though it got most of what it wanted — is seen as taking a stand for Internet freedom.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI

articles.headline: A Smart Breakaway for Big East Basketball Schools
articles.snippet: Reports suggest that the seven Big East schools that do not compete in top-level football might form their own basketball-centric athletic conference, and they might be wise to do it.
articles.abstract: Reports suggest that the seven Big East schools that do not compete in top-level football might form their own basketball-centric athletic conference, and they might be wise to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: A variety of reports suggest that the seven Big East schools that do not compete in high-level football may split off to form their own basketball-centric athletic conference.

articles.headline: On Instagram, a Thriving Bazaar Taps a Big Market
articles.snippet: While Instagram has yet to find a way to make money, many of its users have piggybacked on its popularity and created their own, sometimes quite profitable, businesses.
articles.abstract: While Instagram has yet to find a way to make money, many of its users have piggybacked on its popularity and created their own, sometimes quite profitable, businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Instagram, the picture-sharing application that Facebook bought earlier this year, has not yet figured out a way to make money. But some of its users have.

articles.headline: On Capitol Hill, Fiscal Talks Now Turn to U.S. Borrowing Limit
articles.snippet: The United States is expected to reach its $16.4 trillion debt ceiling at the end of December, starting a countdown to when Washington runs out of money to pay its bills.
articles.abstract: The United States is expected to reach its $16.4 trillion debt ceiling at the end of December, starting a countdown to when Washington runs out of money to pay its bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government is within days of hitting its legal borrowing limit, complicating the already fraught negotiations between the White House and Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio, the de facto leader of the Congressional Republicans.

articles.headline: A Political Brawler, Now Battling for Microsoft
articles.snippet: Mark Penn made a name for himself in Washington by bulldozing enemies of the Clintons. Now he’s trying to do the same to Google, on behalf of its rival Microsoft.
articles.abstract: Mark Penn made a name for himself in Washington by bulldozing enemies of the Clintons. Now he’s trying to do the same to Google, on behalf of its rival Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Mark Penn made a name for himself in Washington by bulldozing enemies of the Clintons. Now he spends his days trying to do the same to Google, on behalf of its archrival Microsoft.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Obama’s Cautious Call for Action Sets Stage to Revive Gun Debate
articles.snippet: In the wake of the deadly shooting in Connecticut, some legislators have remained silent, but liberal Democrats said it was time to move forward with serious gun laws.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the deadly shooting in Connecticut, some legislators have remained silent, but liberal Democrats said it was time to move forward with serious gun laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the emotional statement on the Newtown shootings that President Obama delivered from the White House on Friday, it was a single line, spoken as much in anger as in grief, that stood out. The words were cautious and were immediately criticized for being too timid. But they may have signaled that the long-dormant debate over the nation’s gun laws is about to be re-engaged.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Erica Goode

articles.headline: Opposition to Labor Camps Widens in China
articles.snippet: Opponents of China’s “re-education through labor” system say new leadership could put an end to abuses at the labor camps, which confine perceived troublemakers without trial.
articles.abstract: Opponents of China’s “re-education through labor” system say new leadership could put an end to abuses at the labor camps, which confine perceived troublemakers without trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It is hard to say exactly which “subversive” sentiments drew the police to Ren Jianyu, who posted them on his microblog last year, although “down with dictatorship” and “long live democracy” stand out.

articles.headline: Egypt Islamists Expect Approval of Constitution
articles.snippet: The main group aligned with President Mohamed Morsi predicted ratification of a constitutional referendum after Egyptians voted peacefully and in large numbers.
articles.abstract: The main group aligned with President Mohamed Morsi predicted ratification of a constitutional referendum after Egyptians voted peacefully and in large numbers.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: At Activision, a Hero and Villain, Zapped Into One
articles.snippet: Activision Blizzard, which sells must-have video games like those in the Call of Duty series, may be admired by Wall Street, but players often lash out at the chief executive, Bobby Kotick.
articles.abstract: Activision Blizzard, which sells must-have video games like those in the Call of Duty series, may be admired by Wall Street, but players often lash out at the chief executive, Bobby Kotick.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE who love video games love to hate Bobby Kotick.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Shelved Ideas to Improve Gun Background Checks
articles.snippet: In 2011, the Justice Department proposed an expansion of the background-check system, but it remains unclear whether the Obama administration will take on the powerful gun-rights lobby.
articles.abstract: In 2011, the Justice Department proposed an expansion of the background-check system, but it remains unclear whether the Obama administration will take on the powerful gun-rights lobby.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona and others at a supermarket in Tucson in early 2011, the Justice Department drew up a detailed list of steps the government could take to expand the background-check system in order to reduce the risk of guns falling into the hands of mentally ill people and criminals.

articles.headline: A Light in the 401(k) Tunnel
articles.snippet: The Labor Department has proposed a rule that could help participants in some frozen 401(k) plans gain quicker access to their money.
articles.abstract: The Labor Department has proposed a rule that could help participants in some frozen 401(k) plans gain quicker access to their money.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANOTHER dispatch from 401(k) limbo:

articles.headline: How to Attack the Gender Wage Gap? Speak Up
articles.snippet: When it comes to negotiating for better pay, women often hesitate, studies show. But new programs around the United States are aiming to eliminate those fears.
articles.abstract: When it comes to negotiating for better pay, women often hesitate, studies show. But new programs around the United States are aiming to eliminate those fears.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANNIE HOULE, grandmother of seven, holds up a stack of pink dollar bills.

articles.headline: Quiet Doctor, Lavish Insider: A Parallel Life
articles.snippet: While he appeared a grandfatherly academic, Dr. Sidney Gilman advised a network of Wall Street traders through SAC Capital and eventually crossed the line into criminal behavior.
articles.abstract: While he appeared a grandfatherly academic, Dr. Sidney Gilman advised a network of Wall Street traders through SAC Capital and eventually crossed the line into criminal behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Speaking in front of a packed convention hall in Chicago, a top Alzheimer’s researcher, Sidney Gilman, presented the results of a drug trial that had the potential to change the fate of elderly patients everywhere.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Soured History Hampers Talks Between Obama and Boehner
articles.snippet: President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner have little regard for each other’s bargaining skills, with a relationship damaged by their failure to reach a budget deal 18 months ago.
articles.abstract: President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner have little regard for each other’s bargaining skills, with a relationship damaged by their failure to reach a budget deal 18 months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a closed-door Capitol meeting on Wednesday, Representative Peter Roskam of Illinois was regaling other Republicans with his imitation of Speaker John A. Boehner, imagining him in the current budget negotiations with President Obama. He pretended to drag on a cigarette like the chain-smoking speaker, and blew away smoke and Mr. Obama’s tax demands in one raspy retort: “Ain’t gonna happen.”
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Japan Election Returns Power to Old Guard
articles.snippet: The Liberal Democratic Party was returned to power in parliamentary elections Sunday in what analysts say is more a vote against the incumbents than a mandate.
articles.abstract: The Liberal Democratic Party was returned to power in parliamentary elections Sunday in what analysts say is more a vote against the incumbents than a mandate.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s voters handed a landslide victory to the Liberal Democratic Party in national parliamentary elections on Sunday, giving power back to the conservative party that had governed Japan for decades until a historic defeat three years ago.

articles.headline: Forecast Is Sunnier, but Washington Casts a Big Shadow
articles.snippet: Economists see a number of sources of underlying strength, but some envision slower growth in 2013 even if Washington avoids a stalemate in the fiscal talks.
articles.abstract: Economists see a number of sources of underlying strength, but some envision slower growth in 2013 even if Washington avoids a stalemate in the fiscal talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy could finally have a pretty good year next year — assuming Washington does its part.

articles.headline: Disruptions: Instagram Testimony Doesn’t Add Up
articles.snippet: Kevin Systrom, chief executive of Instagram, insists his company never received any formal acquisition offers besides Facebook’s, but evidence suggests otherwise.
articles.abstract: Kevin Systrom, chief executive of Instagram, insists his company never received any formal acquisition offers besides Facebook’s, but evidence suggests otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a late August morning, Kevin Systrom, chief executive of Instagram, took an oath before testifying at a hearing of the California Corporations Department, which sought to determine if Facebook’s acquisition of the photo sharing service was in the best interest of Instagram investors. Facebook requested the hearing as a way to speed up the approval of its acquisition.

articles.headline: ‘These Tragedies Must End,’ Obama Says
articles.snippet: In a bereaved Connecticut town, President Obama chided the nation for not having done enough to protect its children from attacks like the one Friday that left 20 elementary school students dead.
articles.abstract: In a bereaved Connecticut town, President Obama chided the nation for not having done enough to protect its children from attacks like the one Friday that left 20 elementary school students dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — President Obama vowed on Sunday to “use whatever power this office holds” to stop massacres like the slaughter at the school here that shocked the nation, hinting at a fresh effort to curb the spread of guns as he declared that there was no “excuse for inaction.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Buffeted by the Web, but Now Riding It
articles.snippet: Digital technology has overwhelmed many of those who sought to master it. Brian Lam was both a prince and casualty of it.
articles.abstract: Digital technology has overwhelmed many of those who sought to master it. Brian Lam was both a prince and casualty of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the consumer Web exploded in the mid-1990s, part of the promise was that it would transform careers and the concept of work. Remember the signs on telephone poles and banners all over the Internet? “Work at home and turn your computer into a cash register! Ask me how.” The next generation of Americans would be able to work on their own terms.

articles.headline: Onetime Allies in Antitrust Part Ways Over Google
articles.snippet: Years ago, two lawyers saw Microsoft’s fast grip on the PC software market as anticompetitive. Today, they disagree on whether Google represents a similar force in search.
articles.abstract: Years ago, two lawyers saw Microsoft’s fast grip on the PC software market as anticompetitive. Today, they disagree on whether Google represents a similar force in search.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the digital economy, 14 years is an eternity. Fast-shifting technology means that companies, once feared and seemingly invincible, fade, while new powers rise to dominance, raising fresh sets of concerns.

articles.headline: Apps Give Preschoolers a First Look at TV Shows
articles.snippet: With more parents putting mobile devices into preschoolers’ hands and laps, television networks like Nick Jr. and PBS are turning their focus to educational apps.
articles.abstract: With more parents putting mobile devices into preschoolers’ hands and laps, television networks like Nick Jr. and PBS are turning their focus to educational apps.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2014, the preschool cable network Nick Jr. plans to introduce a television show featuring a little boy, his miniature pet dragon and a magic stick.

articles.headline: Commenting on a Death Gets a Puppet in Trouble
articles.snippet: The latest scandal involves a gossipy, big-haired puppet in Puerto Rico, known as La Comay, who has become one of the island’s most controversial, and most watched, media figures.
articles.abstract: The latest scandal involves a gossipy, big-haired puppet in Puerto Rico, known as La Comay, who has become one of the island’s most controversial, and most watched, media figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a bad few months for puppets in the media.

articles.headline: The Nation Heads Back to School With New Worries About Safety
articles.snippet: Officials and parents spent the weekend anxious about how to talk to students about Friday’s shooting and how best to discourage something like it from happening again.
articles.abstract: Officials and parents spent the weekend anxious about how to talk to students about Friday’s shooting and how best to discourage something like it from happening again.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Boston, the public schools have asked the police to step up visits to elementary schools throughout the day on Monday.

articles.headline: Michigan Effort Shows G.O.P. Sway in State Contests
articles.snippet: Groups that spent millions on the national election have little to show for it, but efforts at the state level — including a drive to set back labor in Michigan — were strikingly successful.
articles.abstract: Groups that spent millions on the national election have little to show for it, but efforts at the state level — including a drive to set back labor in Michigan — were strikingly successful.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Republican leaders in Washington grappled after the election with their failure to unseat President Obama, Dick DeVos, one of Michigan’s wealthiest men, began dialing up state lawmakers in Lansing.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Monica Davey

articles.headline: For Spaniards, Having a Job No Longer Guarantees a Paycheck
articles.snippet: With Spain’s ongoing economic crisis leaving local governments in debt and businesses struggling, workers sometimes have to resort to legal measures simply to be paid.
articles.abstract: With Spain’s ongoing economic crisis leaving local governments in debt and businesses struggling, workers sometimes have to resort to legal measures simply to be paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Spain — Over the past two years, Ana María Molina Cuevas, 36, has worked five shifts a week in a ceramics factory on the outskirts of this city, hand-rolling paint onto tiles. But at the end of the month, she often went unpaid.
